P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
- Quote: "Choledochal cysts are rare congenital cystic dilations of the biliary tree that present primarily in female infants and young children and are more prevalent in East Asian populations [1, 2]. The exact etiology of choledochal cysts is unknown, but anomalous pancreaticobiliary duct union (APBDU) is seen in 30–70 % of all choledochal cysts where the common bile duct (CBD) and pancreatic duct junction occurs outside the duodenum, allowing reflux of pancreatic fluid into the biliary tree [3]. Besides the classic triad of abdominal pain, right upper quadrant mass and obstructive jaundice, choledochal cysts can be associated with serious complications such as cholangitis, pancreatitis, cholelithiasis and have a high risk in developing cholangiocarcinoma [4]. Thus, total cyst excision followed by Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy reconstruction is recommended for most patients with choledochal cysts whenever possible [5]. Laparoscopic excision of choledochal cysts has increasingly gained acceptance and applicability since its first description by Farello [6]. The potential advantages of LH include shorter recovery time and improved cosmesis. However, its safety remains a major concern compared with the conventional open surgery. Therefore, we conducted this meta-analysis to compare the clinical safety and effectiveness of LH with OH."

<PRISMA>
P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
- Quote: "Laparoscopic Versus Open Reduction of Intussusception in Children: A Retrospective Review and Meta-analysis"
- Reasoning: The title identifies the report as a meta-analysis.
- Response: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
- Quote: "Abstract: Background: Intestinal intussusception is a frequent cause of bowel obstruction in children. Initial treatment involves pneumatic reduction. If this fails, operative reduction is indicated. There is controversy regarding use of the laparoscopic (LAP) versus the conventional open approach. Patients and Methods: We performed a retrospective review of all children with intussusception who required operative reduction at our institution over a 12-year time period. We also performed a meta-analysis to combine our data with the published literature. Results: We identified 28 patients requiring operative intervention for reduction of intussusception between January 2000 and April 2012. Five patients underwent LAP reduction, and 23 patients underwent open reduction. Operative times were not statistically different. The rate of overall complications was not statistically different, with 1 of 5 (20%) and 7 of 23 (30%) having complications in the LAP and open groups, respectively. Mean length of stay was 3.8 – 2.1 days in both the LAP and open groups, with no significant difference. Our meta-analysis identified five retrospective studies comparing LAP and open techniques for reduction of intussusception. We did not find a significant difference between groups with respect to operative time, overall complication rates, or re-operation rates. However, the length of hospital stay was significantly longer in the open group. Conclusions: LAP reduction of intussusception is a safe and feasible alternative to the open approach. Length of stay may be shorter in the LAP group."
- Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary of the study.
- Response: [Yes]

- Quote: "Intussusception in children may result in significant morbidity and mortality if not treated in a timely fashion. If initial treatment with enema reductions is not successful, patients require operative intervention. Controversy exists as to whether the laparoscopic (LAP) operative approach is as safe and effective as the standard open approach."
- Reasoning: The authors provide a rationale for the review in the context of existing knowledge.

<PRISMA>
P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
- Quote: "Abstract: Background: Intestinal intussusception is a frequent cause of bowel obstruction in children. Initial treatment involves pneumatic reduction. If this fails, operative reduction is indicated. There is controversy regarding use of the laparoscopic (LAP) versus the conventional open approach. Patients and Methods: We performed a retrospective review of all children with intussusception who required operative reduction at our institution over a 12-year time period. We also performed a meta-analysis to combine our data with the published literature. Results: We identified 28 patients requiring operative intervention for reduction of intussusception between January 2000 and April 2012. Five patients underwent LAP reduction, and 23 patients underwent open reduction. Operative times were not statistically different. The rate of overall complications was not statistically different, with 1 of 5 (20%) and 7 of 23 (30%) having complications in the LAP and open groups, respectively. Mean length of stay was 3.8 – 2.1 days in both the LAP and open groups, with no significant difference. Our meta-analysis identified five retrospective studies comparing LAP and open techniques for reduction of intussusception. We did not find a significant difference between groups with respect to operative time, overall complication rates, or re-operation rates. However, the length of hospital stay was significantly longer in the open group. Conclusions: LAP reduction of intussusception is a safe and feasible alternative to the open approach. Length of stay may be shorter in the LAP group."
- Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary of the study.
- Response: [Yes]

<PRISMA>
P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
Quotes: "Title: Laparoendoscopic single-site surgery (LESS) for major urological procedures in the pediatric population: A systematic review"
Reasoning: The title clearly identifies the report as a systematic review.
Response: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
Quotes: "Abstract: Background: Improvements in laparoscopic surgery have led to the introduction of laparoendoscopic single-site surgery (LESS) as an alternative to conventional laparoscopy conferring a number of possible advantages. In this review, we aim to elucidate the aspects of LESS for major urological procedures in the pediatric population. Materials and methods: An in-depth search of the literature was performed in the databases of PubMed and Scopus, for studies investigating the technical aspects and clinical outcomes of partial nephrec- tomies, nephrectomies, nephroureterectomies, varicocelectomies and pyeloplasties in children. Data on parameters such as operation time, instrumentation, perioperative complications, hospital stay and follow up period were collected and further analyzed cumulatively. Results: Twenty nine studies met the inclusion criteria incorporating 386 patients who underwent 401 procedures. There were no major intraoperative complications, with only 19 patients (4.73%) facing postoperative complications. No perioperative deaths were reported. Conclusions: In the hands of experienced surgeons LESS seems a feasible, efficient and less invasive alternative to standard laparoscopy in the field of pediatric urology. There is an eminent need of well- designed randomized controlled trials comparing the two techniques."
Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary of the review, including background, objectives, methods, results, and conclusions.
Response: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
Quotes: "Laparoscopic surgery is currently the gold standard for the surgical management of pediatric urologic pathologies [1]. Recent improvements in laparoscopic surgical techniques have led to the introduction of laparoendoscopic single-site surgery (LESS), as an alternative to conventional laparoscopy (CL) conferring a number of possible advantages: better esthetic outcome, decreased incidence of port-site complications, less postoperative pain, reduced anal- gesic requirements and faster recovery [2]."
Reasoning: The authors provide a rationale for the review in the context of existing knowledge.
Response: [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
Quotes: "In this review, we aim to elucidate the aspects of LESS for major urological procedures in the pediatric population."
Reasoning: The authors provide an explicit statement of the questions being addressed.
Response: [Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.
Quotes: No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors do not mention a review protocol or registration information.
Response: [No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
Quotes: "Inclusion criteria were: 1) pediatric patient population (age <18 years) 2) single site approach initially selected by the surgeon, 3) procedure carried out completely laparoendoscopically, 4) major urological procedure performed were limited to: nephrectomy, nephrour- ureterectomy, pyeloplasty, varicocelectomy and partial nephrectomy 5) study population of more than one patient. Studies of any design, including studies comparing CL and LESS, were eligible for inclu- sion. Articles in language other than English, and studies reporting on animal models and mixed adult and pediatric population were excluded."
Reasoning: The authors specify the study and report characteristics used as criteria for eligibility.

<PRISMA>
P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
Quotes: "Title: Laparoendoscopic single-site surgery (LESS) for major urological procedures in the pediatric population: A systematic review"
Reasoning: The title clearly identifies the report as a systematic review.
Response: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
Quotes: "Abstract: Background: Improvements in laparoscopic surgery have led to the introduction of laparoendoscopic single-site surgery (LESS) as an alternative to conventional laparoscopy conferring a number of possible advantages. In this review, we aim to elucidate the aspects of LESS for major urological procedures in the pediatric population. Materials and methods: An in-depth search of the literature was performed in the databases of PubMed and Scopus, for studies investigating the technical aspects and clinical outcomes of partial nephrec- tomies, nephrectomies, nephroureterectomies, varicocelectomies and pyeloplasties in children. Data on parameters such as operation time, instrumentation, perioperative complications, hospital stay and follow up period were collected and further analyzed cumulatively. Results: Twenty nine studies met the inclusion criteria incorporating 386 patients who underwent 401 procedures. There were no major intraoperative complications, with only 19 patients (4.73%) facing postoperative complications. No perioperative deaths were reported. Conclusions: In the hands of experienced surgeons LESS seems a feasible, efficient and less invasive alternative to standard laparoscopy in the field of pediatric urology. There is an eminent need of well- designed randomized controlled trials comparing the two techniques."
Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary of the review, including background, objectives, methods, results, and conclusions.
Response: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
Quotes: "Laparoscopic surgery is currently the gold standard for the surgical management of pediatric urologic pathologies [1]. Recent improvements in laparoscopic surgical techniques have led to the introduction of laparoendoscopic single-site surgery (LESS), as an alternative to conventional laparoscopy (CL) conferring a number of possible advantages: better esthetic outcome, decreased incidence of port-site complications, less postoperative pain, reduced anal- gesic requirements and faster recovery [2]."
Reasoning: The authors provide a rationale for the review in the context of existing knowledge.
Response: [Yes]

Quotes: "Inclusion criteria were: 1) pediatric patient population (age <18 years) 2) single site approach initially selected by the surgeon, 3) procedure carried out completely laparoendoscopically, 4) major urological procedure performed were limited to: nephrectomy, nephrour- ureterectomy, pyeloplasty, varicocelectomy and partial nephrectomy 5) study population of more than one patient. P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.
Quote: "Medline, Embase, Cinahl, and Cochrane databases were searched electronically on April 24, 2014, and then updated on May 11, 2015; the search was limited to reports published after January 1, 1980."
Reasoning: The authors describe the databases they searched and the dates of their search.
Response: [Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.
Quote: "One author and 2 librarians were involved in the search, and combinations of the relevant medical subject heading terms, key words, and word variants for “isomerism,” “heterotaxy,” “situs ambiguous,” “Ivemark,” and “malrotation” were used."
Reasoning: The authors provide some details about their search strategy, but do not provide enough information for it to be fully replicated.
Response: [No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).
Quote: "Two authors reviewed all the abstracts independently. Agreement regarding potential relevance was reached by consensus. Full-text copies of potentially eligible papers were obtained, and the same 2 reviewers independently extracted relevant data on study characteristics and the outcomes of interest."
Reasoning: The authors describe the process they used to select studies for inclusion in the review.
Response: [Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.
Quote: "Two authors reviewed all the abstracts independently. Agreement regarding potential relevance was reached by consensus. Full-text copies of potentially eligible papers were obtained, and the same 2 reviewers independently extracted relevant data on study characteristics and the outcomes of interest."
Reasoning: The authors describe the process they used to extract data from the included studies.
Response: [Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.
Quote: "The outcomes investigated in this systematic review were as follows: (1) incidence of IRA in heterotaxy; (2) detection rate when screening asymptomatic heterotaxy for IRA; (3) incidence of midgut volvulus in heterotaxy cases not screened for IRA; and (4) morbidity and mortality associated with elective prophylactic and emergency Ladd procedures to treat IRA in heterotaxy."
Reasoning: The authors list the variables for which they sought data.
Response: [Yes]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.
Quote: "Quality assessment of the included studies was performed using the Newcastle-Ottawa Scale (NOS) for cohort and case-control studies."
Reasoning: The authors describe the method they used to assess the risk of bias in the included studies.
Response: [Yes]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).
Quote: "We used meta-analyses of proportions to combine the data."
Reasoning: The authors state that they used meta-analyses of proportions as their principal summary measure.
Response: [Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.
Quote: "Between-study heterogeneity was explored graphically within the forest plot and assessed by the use of the I2 statistic, which represents the percentage between-study variation that is attributable to heterogeneity rather than chance."
Reasoning: The authors describe the methods they used to handle data and combine the results of the included studies.
Response: [Yes]

P15. Methdos / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).
Quote: "Publication bias was explored by the use of funnel plots and was assessed statistically with the Begg and Mazumdar rank correlation test and Egger tests."
Reasoning: The authors specify that they assessed the risk of publication bias.

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified.
Quote: Not available.
Reasoning: The authors do not mention any additional analyses.

P17. Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.

P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.
Quote: "Screening in asymptomatic cases has a high positive detection rate of IRA (58%). The risk of developing acute midgut volvulus, requiring an emergency laparotomy in patients never screened for IRA, was 5.8%."

Response: [Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies (see Item P15).

Quote: Not available.

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.

P2. P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).
- Quote: "Risk ratios (RRs) and 95 % confidential intervals (CIs) were determined using RevMan 5.3 software."
- Reasoning: The authors stated the principal summary measures used in the review.

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).
- Quote: "There was very serious risk of bias due to inappropriate patient selection, unequal follow-up durations, and the absence of controlling for confounding."

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified.

- Quote: "Of 264 search results, 226 studies were excluded based on titles and abstracts. After screening the remaining 38 studies based on their full texts, 14 studies were included in the qualitative synthesis."
- Reasoning: The authors provided the numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review.

P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.
- Quote: "The eight observational studies were included in a quantitative synthesis."

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12).
- Quote: "As assessed on the GRADE scale, the quality of evidence was very low for all outcomes."

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.
- Quote: "The incidence of overall mortality was higher in the OS group than in the ES group (RR = 0.18; 95 % CI 0.09–0.38; z = 4.48; p < 0.00001; Fig. 3)."
- Reasoning: The authors presented the results of individual studies, including effect estimates and confidence intervals.
- Answer: [Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
- Quote: "The risk of recurrence was higher in the ES group than in the OS group (RR = 3.10; 95 % CI 1.95–4.94; z = 4.78; p < 0.00001; Fig. 4)."
- Reasoning: The authors presented the results of the meta-analysis, including confidence intervals.
- Answer: [Yes]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies (see Item P15).
- Quote: "There was very serious risk of bias due to inappropriate patient selection, unequal follow-up durations, and the absence of controlling for confounding."

- Quote: "In conclusion, evidence for the effectiveness of ES in CDH neonates remains insufficient."
- Reasoning: The authors summarized the main findings and considered their relevance to key groups.
- Answer: [Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).
- Quote: "As derived in the present study, the best available evidence showed that ES had an unclear effect on mortality in neonatal CDH, and that the recurrence rate in the ES group was clearly higher than that in the OS group."
- Reasoning: The authors discussed the limitations of the study.
- Answer: [Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.
- Quote: "Therefore, ES should not be the routine treatment for every neonate. It is crucially important to select suitable cases for ES, but the details of this selection remain a topic for future discussion."

- Reasoning: The authors described the sources of funding for the systematic review.

llm_message:
<AMSTAR>
A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
- Quote: "Before the formal literature search, the protocol was prospectively registered at the international registry of systematic reviews, PROSPERO (registration number CRD42015016420)."
- Reasoning: The authors mention that the protocol was prospectively registered.
- Answer: [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
- Quote: "The 2 reviewers, R.N.W.V. and E.N.B. independently reviewed all study abstracts in duplicate with disagreements resolved by the senior author (J.C.R.). Full-text articles appearing to meet selection criteria were reviewed, and study data was abstracted in the same manner."
- Reasoning: The authors mention that two reviewers independently reviewed the studies and resolved disagreements.
- Answer: [Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
- Quote: "We searched MEDLINE, EMBASE, the Cochrane Controlled Trials Register, Google Scholar, and Scopus electronic databases for studies published between 1980 and 2014 based on Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) guidelines [19]."
- Reasoning: The authors mention that they searched multiple databases and followed PRISMA guidelines.
- Answer: [Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
- Quote: "We also manually searched for unpublished abstracts presented at relevant scientific meetings: the American Urological Association, the American Academy of Pediatrics Section on Urology, the Pediatric Academic Societies, the American Pediatric Surgical Association, and the European Society of Pediatric Urology."
- Reasoning: The authors mention that they searched for unpublished abstracts from scientific meetings.
- Answer: [Yes]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
- Quote: "A total of 66 studies met all criteria for inclusion and were included in the final review (Fig. 1)."
- Reasoning: The authors mention the number of studies included but do not provide a list of included and excluded studies.
- Answer: [No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
- Quote: "Of the 66 included studies, most (60, 91%) were retrospective cohorts or case series, including 1 administrative database analysis that also met inclusion criteria. Only 6 (9%) studies reported prospective data."
- Reasoning: The authors provide some characteristics of the included studies, such as the type of study and the number of studies of each type.
- Answer: [Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
- Quote: "Most included studies were retrospective case series with highly variable reporting quality; this made data abstraction particularly challenging."
- Reasoning: The authors mention the quality of the included studies but do not provide a detailed assessment.
- Answer: [No]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
- Quote: "However, these studies are significantly limited by their inherent methodological flaws; notably, to the best of our knowledge there is no randomized controlled trial of NSS and RN use in children with WT."
- Reasoning: The authors mention the limitations of the included studies in their conclusions.
- Answer: [Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
- Quote: "Owing to these differences in reporting among studies in conjunction with a lack of individual patient data, direct comparisons of outcomes data (e.g., overall or event-free survival rates after RN and NSS) was not performed."
- Reasoning: The authors did not combine the findings of the studies due to differences in reporting and lack of individual patient data.
- Answer: [NA]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
- Quote: Not applicable.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention assessing the likelihood of publication bias.
- Answer: [No]

- Quote: "Abstract: Introduction: Radical nephrectomy (RN, or total nephrectomy) is the current gold-standard surgical treatment for children with Wilms tumors (WT). However, nephron-sparing surgery (NSS, or partial nephrectomy) has recently been gaining increasing attention. The objective of this systematic review is to compare the effectiveness of NSS as compared with RN for the treatment of children with WT. Methods: We searched the Cochrane Controlled Trials Register, clinicaltrials.gov, MEDLINE, EMBASE, Google Scholar, and recently presented meeting abstracts for reports in English. The bibliographies of included studies were then hand-searched for any missed articles. The protocol was prospectively registered. Manuscripts were assessed and data abstracted in duplicate with differences resolved by the senior author. Owing to high heterogeneity among the final included studies, only a qualitative systematic review was performed; no formal meta-analysis was undertaken. Results: We identified 694 articles, 118 of which were selected for full-text review and 66 of which were included in the final analysis. Most studies were single- or multi-institution retrospective case series (60, 91%), with a small number of prospective cohort studies (6, 9%) and 1 administrative database analysis. Most studies were from Europe (27, 41%) or North America (21, 32%). Nearly half (32, 48%) of studies those were included were dated from 2010 or later. Reported rupture rates were similar between RN and NSS (13% vs. 7%), as were recurrence rates (12% vs. 11%) and survival rates (85% vs. 88%). However, these comparisons are limited by inherent biases in the design and reporting of most included studies. Conclusions: Most contemporary studies reporting the use of NSS in children with WT report similar long-term outcomes to RN. However, most existing studies are limited by their small numbers, inconsistent reporting, and methodological biases. There are significant opportunities for future research on the use of NSS in children with WT, including issues related to surgical quality, optimal technique, timing and duration of chemotherapy, and variation in the use of NSS among centers. r 2016 Elsevier Inc. A total of 66 studies met all criteria for inclusion and were included in the final review (Fig. 1)."

<PRISMA>
P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
Quotes: "To Split or Not to Split: Colostomy Complications for Anorectal Malformations or Hirschsprung Disease: A Single Center Experience and a Systematic Review of the Literature"
Reasoning: The title clearly identifies the report as a systematic review.
Response: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
Quotes: "Abstract: Introduction The aim of this article is to identify the ideal type and location of colostomy in children with colorectal disease. Patients and Methods A retrospective case study of children with an anorectal malformation who received a colostomy, born between January 1990 and July 2012. Furthermore, a systematic literature search on colostomies in neonates with an anorectal malformation or Hirschsprung disease. Colostomies were classified as loop or split colostomies in the transverse or sigmoid colon. Outcome measures were mortality and complications such as prolapse, technical difficulties with the reconstruction, urinary tract infections, and others. Results The mortality rate in the 180 children with anorectal malformation was 6%, and none of them were directly related to stoma formation or closure. The overall complication rate was 23% and the specific rates for the two types of procedures and the two locations of the colostomy did not differ (p ¼ 0.389 and p ¼ 0.667, respectively). All prolapses (n ¼ 22) occurred in loop colostomies in the transverse colon. One colostomy required revision because of insufficient length for the reconstruction. Urinary tract infections were not documented. A total of eight studies were included in the systematic review (1982–2011; 2,954 patients). Mortality ranged between 0.1 and 11%. Loop colostomies had more complications than split colostomies (63 vs. 45%; p ¼ 0.007), mainly prolapse (18 vs. 6%; p < 0.001). Overall complication rate differed between transverse en sigmoid colostomies (62 vs. 51%, p ¼ 0.006), and prolapse occurred more often in the transverse colon (23 vs. 7%; p < 0.001). Revision because of insufficient length during the reconstruction was needed in 0 to 6%. Two studies reported on urinary tract infections which are as follows: One showed no difference between loop or split colostomies, whereas the other showed frequent episodes of urinary tract infections in 64% of the loop colostomies. Conclusions The complication to be avoided in transverse colostomies is prolapse and the surgical technique should be modified accordingly. The procedure of split sigmoid colostomy is meticulous, and the risk of insufficient length for the reconstruction remains."
Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary of the study, including the background, objectives, methods, results, and conclusions.
Response: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
Quotes: "Anorectal malformations and Hirschsprung disease are congenital malformations that show a wide clinical variety. In children with a high anorectal malformation, a colostomy is constructed in the neonatal period when direct reconstruction in the first few days of life is not possible. The colostomy is closed after reconstructive surgery later in life. In children with Hirschsprung disease, a stoma is formed if the bowel cannot be decompressed with the use of rectal washouts. The stoma is closed after the aganglionic bowel has been resected and a pull-through procedure has been performed."
Reasoning: The authors provide a rationale for the review in the context of what is already known about anorectal malformations and Hirschsprung disease.
Response: [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
Quotes: "The aim of this article is to identify the ideal type and location of colostomy in children with colorectal disease."
Reasoning: The authors provide an explicit statement of the research question, but they do not explicitly mention the PICOS components.
Response: [No]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.
Quotes: None.
Reasoning: The text does not provide information on whether a review protocol exists or where it can be accessed.
Response: [No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
Quotes: "Studies were eligible for inclusion when they reported a series of neonates (newborns under the age of 28 days) whose anorectal malformation or Hirschsprung disease was treated with a stoma, and reported on stoma type and location, complications of stoma formation or closure or mortality rates. Studies excluded were the case series of less than 10 patients, articles that were not written in English, and articles that did not provide information on stoma type and location. Studies from developing countries were excluded because of the different setting compared with the developed countries. In case of duplicate publications, the most recent publication was included."
Reasoning: The authors specify the study characteristics and report characteristics used as criteria for eligibility and provide a rationale for their choices.
Response: [Yes]

Reasoning: The authors describe the information sources used in the search, but they do not provide the dates of coverage or the date of the last search.
Response: [No]

Quote: "ABSTRACT Background Children with neurological impairments frequently experience feeding difficulties, which can lead to malnutrition and growth failure" [...] "Authors' conclusions There remains considerable uncertainty regarding the optimal treatment when faced with the decision of fundoplication surgery versus antireflux medications for children with GOR and neurological impairment who are undergoing gastrostomy insertion."

Response: [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
Quote: "To compare the effectiveness of antireflux surgery and antireflux medications for children with neurological impairments and GOR who are undergoing placement of a gastrostomy feeding tube."

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
Quotes: "In approximately 2–5 % of males, one or both testes fail to descend into the scrotum by birth" [...] "However, surgical correction of IAT is often technically challenging, as the testicular vessels may not be of sufficient length to allow mobilization of the testis into the scrotum."
Reasoning: The authors provide a rationale for the review in the context of the existing knowledge about the topic.
Response: [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
Quotes: "We conducted a systematic review of literature focusing on the surgical treatment of IAT, including quality assessment of each study."
Reasoning: The authors provide an explicit statement of the questions being addressed, but do not explicitly mention the PICOS components.

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.

Response: [No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
Quotes: "We included all studies that examined diagnostic and surgical correction techniques for IAT, even if this was not the primary focus of the study. Our outcomes of interest were success of orchiopexy (testis viable and located in the scrotum), testicular atrophy, and intra-operative and post-operative complications."
Reasoning: The authors specify the study characteristics and outcomes of interest used as criteria for eligibility.

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.
Quotes: "We conducted electronic searches of the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), MEDLINE, EMBASE, and CINAHL from inception to September 2014."
Reasoning: The authors describe the databases searched and the time frame for the search.
Response: [Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.

Quotes: "One reviewer extracted data from each of the included studies, and a second reviewer checked the data for accu- racy and completeness."
Reasoning: The authors describe the data extraction process.
Response: [Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.
Quotes: "Our outcomes of interest were success of orchiopexy (testis viable and located in the scrotum), testicular atrophy, and intra-operative and post-operative complications."
Reasoning: The authors list the outcomes of interest, but do not define all variables for which data were sought.

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.
Quotes: "Two researchers" [...] "quality assessed each relevant study using AMSTAR for systematic reviews (SRs), Cochrane ‘Risk of bias’ tool for randomized controlled trials (RCTs), and MINORS for non-randomized studies."
Reasoning: The authors describe the tools used for assessing the quality of the included studies, which includes an assessment of risk of bias.
Response: [Yes]

Reasoning: The authors explain why a meta-analysis was not performed, but do not describe any other methods of synthesizing results.

Reasoning: The authors provide numbers of studies at each stage of the selection process, but do not provide a flow diagram.

Quotes: "The remaining 31 studies comprised two SRs and 29 non-randomized studies; we quality assessed and summarized these studies (Table 1)."
Reasoning: The authors mention summarizing the characteristics of the included studies in a table.

Quotes: "Due to the heterogeneity of the data, a meta-analysis was not possible."
Reasoning: The authors explain why a meta-analysis was not performed.
Response: [NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies (see Item P15).
Quotes: No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors do not present results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies.
Response: [No]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression [see Item P16]).
Quotes: No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors do not mention conducting any additional analyses.
Response: [No]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).
Quotes: "Our overall finding is that there is a paucity of good-quality evidence on this topic" [...] "We cautiously recommend the following: location and diagnosis of IAT should be conducted via laparoscopy, followed by inguinal canal exploration if necessary; low IAT should be corrected by primary orchiopexy, while high IAT should be corrected by either one- or two-stage FSO, according to the surgeon’s preference; the decision to perform an open or laparoscopic procedure should also be based on the surgeon’s preference."
Reasoning: The authors summarize the main findings and provide recommendations based on the strength of the evidence.
Response: [Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).
Quotes: "This is a fairly comprehensive systematic review, as our search included four major databases; however, it is possible that we missed some evidence by limiting our review to English language, published literature" [...] "Despite these biases, we elected to consider non-randomized studies for inclusion in our review, due to the overall lack of evidence from RCTs available in the surgical literature."
Reasoning: The authors discuss the limitations of their review.
Response: [Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.
Quotes: "Further studies—particularly RCTs—are needed to confirm the validity of these recommendations, and to improve the current surgical techniques for optimization of long-term outcomes."
Reasoning: The authors provide a general interpretation of the results and discuss implications for future research.
Response: [Yes]

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.
Quotes: No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors do not mention any sources of funding or other support for the review.
Response: [No]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?

- Reasoning: The authors mention the use of multiple search terms and the Medline database, but do not mention the use of any other databases or supplementary search strategies.

- Quote: Not available.

- Quote: Not available.
- Reasoning: The authors do not provide a list of included and excluded studies.

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
- Quote: "There are three main approaches toward the treatment of SBS. These are: 1. Surgical approaches 2. Non-surgical approaches 3. Tissue engineering"
- Reasoning: The authors provide a general overview of the types of studies included, but do not provide specific details about the participants, interventions, and outcomes of each study.
- Answer: [No]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
- Quote: Not available.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention any assessment of the scientific quality of the included studies.
- Answer: [No]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
- Quote: Not available.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention the scientific quality of the included studies in their conclusions.

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
- Quote: Not available.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention any methods used to combine the findings of the included studies.

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
- Quote: Not available.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention any assessment of publication bias.

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?

<AMSTAR>

- Quote: "Methods: For this meta-analysis, the Medline (1990e2009), Embase (1990e2009) and Cochrane databases were searched using the keyword ‘hypospadias’. Inclusion criteria were: i) primary repairs; ii) distal hypospadias; iii) paediatric case series; iv) standard Mathieu and TIP techniques; v) complication data obtainable from the paper."
- Reasoning: The authors have clearly stated their research question and inclusion criteria.

<PRISMA>
P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
- Quote: "Outcomes in distal hypospadias: A systematic review of the Mathieu and tubularized incised plate repairs"
- Reasoning: The title clearly identifies the report as a systematic review.
- Response: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
- Quote: "Abstract Aim: To compare complication rates after distal hypospadias surgery using the tubularized incised plate (TIP) and Mathieu techniques. Methods: For this meta-analysis, the Medline (1990e2009), Embase (1990e2009) and Cochrane databases were searched using the keyword ‘hypospadias’. Inclusion criteria were: i) primary repairs; ii) distal hypospadias; iii) paediatric case series; iv) standard Mathieu and TIP techniques; v) complication data obtainable from the paper. Cases were only included in the denominator for each complication if explicitly identified in the paper. Fisher’s exact was used for statistical analysis, with P < 0.05 considered significant. Main results: 129 papers were selected for full analysis; 23 papers met the inclusion criteria comprising 1872 TIP repairs and 1496 Mathieu repairs. We identified an increased incidence of urethral fistulae with the Mathieu technique (3.8% vs 5.3%, P Z 0.028); however, this is lost on subgroup analysis. An increased incidence of meatal stenosis was identified in the TIP group (3.1% vs 0.7%, P < 0.001). Conclusions: There is no clear consensus on the ideal method of repair for distal hypospadias. Both the Mathieu and TIP techniques have been shown to have low rates of postoperative complications. Comparison between series is difficult because of a lack of consistency in reporting complications and follow up. We advocate uniform standards for reporting outcomes of hypospadias."
- Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary of the review, including background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, methods, results, and conclusions.
- Response: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
- Quote: "Hypospadias is one of the most common congenital conditions affecting males worldwide. Over 200 different repairs are described in the available literature although two repairs, the tubularized incised plate (TIP) repair and the Mathieu technique, dominate the current literature."
- Reasoning: The authors provide a rationale for the review in the context of the existing literature.
- Response: [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
- Quote: "Aim: To compare complication rates after distal hypospadias surgery using the tubularized incised plate (TIP) and Mathieu techniques."
- Reasoning: The authors provide an explicit statement of the question being addressed, including participants (patients undergoing distal hypospadias surgery), interventions (TIP and Mathieu techniques), and outcomes (complication rates).
- Response: [Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.
- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention a review protocol or registration.
- Response: [No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
- Quote: "Our inclusion criteria were: i) primary repairs only, ii) clearly defined series of exclusively distal hypospadias, iii) paediatric case series, iv) standard Mathieu and TIP techniques, and v) complication data obtainable from the paper. Letters, review articles, case reports and duplicate patient series were excluded."
- Reasoning: The authors specify the study characteristics and report characteristics used as criteria for eligibility.
- Response: [Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.
- Quote: "The Medline (1990eDec 2009), Embase (1990eDec 2009) and Cochrane databases were searched using the single search term ‘hypospadias’ to ensure the broadest capture of relevant papers."
- Reasoning: The authors describe the information sources and the date range of the search.
- Response: [Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.
- Quote: "The Medline (1990eDec 2009), Embase (1990eDec 2009) and Cochrane databases were searched using the single search term ‘hypospadias’ to ensure the broadest capture of relevant papers."
- Reasoning: The authors present the search strategy for three databases, but do not provide enough detail for the search to be repeated.
- Response: [No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).
- Quote: "The search, selection and review of papers, and statistical analysis were conducted by both primary authors. The references of included papers were reviewed to identify potential additional series not identified in the initial database search. All titles and abstracts were reviewed initially to select papers for full review if they contained results of distal hypospadias repairs using either the Mathieu or TIP repair. Where the relevance of a paper was unclear a review of the full paper was undertaken."
- Reasoning: The authors describe the process for selecting studies.

<PRISMA>
P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
- Quote: "Outcomes in distal hypospadias: A systematic review of the Mathieu and tubularized incised plate repairs"
- Reasoning: The title clearly identifies the report as a systematic review.
- Response: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
- Quote: "Abstract Aim: To compare complication rates after distal hypospadias surgery using the tubularized incised plate (TIP) and Mathieu techniques. Methods: For this meta-analysis, the Medline (1990e2009), Embase (1990e2009) and Cochrane databases were searched using the keyword ‘hypospadias’. Inclusion criteria were: i) primary repairs; ii) distal hypospadias; iii) paediatric case series; iv) standard Mathieu and TIP techniques; v) complication data obtainable from the paper. Cases were only included in the denominator for each complication if explicitly identified in the paper. Fisher’s exact was used for statistical analysis, with P < 0.05 considered significant. Main results: 129 papers were selected for full analysis; 23 papers met the inclusion criteria comprising 1872 TIP repairs and 1496 Mathieu repairs. We identified an increased incidence of urethral fistulae with the Mathieu technique (3.8% vs 5.3%, P Z 0.028); however, this is lost on subgroup analysis. An increased incidence of meatal stenosis was identified in the TIP group (3.1% vs 0.7%, P < 0.001). Conclusions: There is no clear consensus on the ideal method of repair for distal hypospadias. Both the Mathieu and TIP techniques have been shown to have low rates of postoperative complications. Comparison between series is difficult because of a lack of consistency in reporting complications and follow up. We advocate uniform standards for reporting outcomes of hypospadias."
- Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary of the review, including background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, methods, results, and conclusions.
- Response: [Yes]

llm_message:
<AMSTAR>
A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
- Quote: "The purpose of this study was to review the current literature and perform a systemic review and meta-analysis to determine the efficacy of LH in the repair of PIH."
- Reasoning: The authors state the research question and the method (systematic review and meta-analysis) they will use to answer it.
- Answer: [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
- Quote: "The citations, abstracts, or full text of all potentially relevant studies were independently evaluated and selected by 3 reviewers (YCL, ZHY, and TQS), and any disagreements were resolved by consensus."
- Reasoning: The authors mention that three reviewers independently evaluated and selected the studies, indicating a duplicate study selection and data extraction process.
- Answer: [Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
- Quote: "All published studies until July 30, 2010, were searched with the terms laparoscopy, laparoscopic herniorrhaphy, pediatric inguinal hernia, and open herniorrhaphy from Medline (using PubMed as the search engine), Embase, Ovid, Web of Science, and Cochrane databases, without lower date limit."
- Reasoning: The authors describe a comprehensive literature search across multiple databases using specific search terms.
- Answer: [Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
- Quote: "This review was limited to the published studies, and no contact was made with the authors to obtain unpublished data."
- Reasoning: The authors explicitly state that they limited their review to published studies, indicating that they did not include grey literature.
- Answer: [No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
- Quote: "One hundred thirty-eight studies were initially found to report the LH in the management of PIH using the keywords laparoscopy and pediatric inguinal hernia."
- Reasoning: The authors mention the number of studies initially found but do not provide a list of these studies.
- Answer: [No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
- Quote: "A summary of the studies' method, intervention characteristics, and measured outcomes was provided in Table 1, Table 2, and Table 3, including 1543 cases of LH and 657 cases of OH."
- Reasoning: The authors provide tables summarizing the characteristics of the included studies.
- Answer: [Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
- Quote: "Each included article was appraised by 3 reviewers (YCL, ZHY, and TQS), who assessed the methodological quality of the selected studies independently. A critical review checklist of the Dutch Cochrane Centre was used to appraise the RCTs."
- Reasoning: The authors mention that they assessed the methodological quality of the included studies using a critical review checklist.
- Answer: [Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
- Quote: "In this systemic review and meta-analysis, we demonstrated that LH is efficient for the inguinal hernia repair in children, with similar operative time for unilateral hernia, length of hospital stay, recurrence, and complication rates with OH."
- Reasoning: The authors' conclusions are based on the results of their systematic review and meta-analysis, indicating that they considered the scientific quality of the included studies.
- Answer: [Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
- Quote: "Weighted mean differences (WMDs) and ORs were used for the analysis of continuous and dichotomous variables, respectively."
- Reasoning: The authors describe the statistical methods they used to combine the findings of the included studies.
- Answer: [Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
- Quote: "Because of the limited case number and insufficient data, the current meta-analysis possesses potential shortcomings to exactly compare some essential parameters between LH and OH, such as theater time, cost, quality of treatment, and postoperative MCIH."
- Reasoning: The authors acknowledge potential shortcomings in their meta-analysis, but they do not specifically assess the likelihood of publication bias.
- Answer: [No]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
- Quote: "This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (no. 30200284, no. 30600278, no. 30772359, no. 81071997, no. 81072073), Program for New Century Excellent Talents in University (NCET-06-0641), Scientific Research Foundation for the Returned Overseas Chinese Scholars (2008-889), and Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities (2010JC025)."
- Reasoning: The authors disclose the sources of funding for their systematic review.
- Answer: [Yes]

<PRISMA>
P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
- Quote: "Laparoscopic vs open herniorrhaphy in the management of pediatric inguinal hernia: a systemic review and meta-analysis"
- Reasoning: The title clearly identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
- Answer: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
- Quote: "Abstract: Purpose: Laparoscopic herniorrhaphy (LH) has been evolved as a minimally invasive technique for pediatric inguinal hernias (PIHs). Considerable debate exists regarding the benefits of LH over conventional open herniorrhaphy (OH). The aim of this review was to critique the current literature to determine the efficacy of LH. Methods: Published studies until July 30, 2010, were searched from Medline, Embase, Ovid, Web of Science, and Cochrane databases. Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and observational clinical studies (OCSs) with a comparison of LH and OH were included. A systemic review and meta-analysis were performed using the odds ratios (ORs) for dichotomous variables and weighted mean differences (WMDs) for continuous variables. Results: Of 138 studies, 3 RCTs and 4 OCSs were eligible for inclusion criteria, comprising 1543 cases of LH and 657 cases of OH. Compared with OH, shorter operative time for bilateral hernias (WMD = −11.14; 95% confidence interval [CI], −20.61 to −1.68; P = .02) and lower rate of metachronic contralateral hernia (OR, 0.26; 95% CI, 0.09-0.76; P = .01) were noted in LH. However, no significant difference was observed between LH and OH in patients' age, sex, affected side, operative time for unilateral hernias, duration of hospital stay, time to resume full activity, recurrence, and complications. Conclusions: Laparoscopic herniorrhaphy is superior to OH in the repair of bilateral PIH and lower rate of metachronic contralateral hernia, with similar operative time for unilateral hernias, length of hospital stay, recurrence, and complication rates. Because of the publishing bias, a series of RCTs with standard report format and uniform unit are necessary to explore the efficiencies of LH in the management of PIH."
- Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary of the background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants, interventions, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, and conclusions.
- Answer: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
- Quote: "Inguinal hernias, one of the inguinoscrotal abnormalities because of failure to close the processus vaginalis, are common conditions of infancy and childhood [1]. Herniotomy is the standard procedure for pediatric inguinal hernia (PIH), with a high success rate and low rate of complications [2]. The principle for the repair of PIH is the complete ligation of patent processus vaginalis [3]. Some patients develop hernia on the opposite side after surgical repair, which is known as metachronous contralateral inguinal hernia (MCIH) [4]. Recurrence after an open procedure may be attributed to a failure to ligate the sac high enough at the internal ring, injury to the floor of inguinal canal because of operative trauma, failure to close the internal ring in girls, or postoperative wound infection and hematoma [5]. Therefore, contralateral exploration and postoperative hernia recurrence remain the major problems of conventional open herniorrhaphy (OH) in children with an indirect hernia [5]. In addition, injury to the reproductive system is the most frequent causes of infertility because of childhood inguinal herniorrhaphy [6]. Thus, it remains one of the duties for pediatric surgeons to improve the treatment of inguinal hernias."
- Reasoning: The authors provide a rationale for the review in the context of what is already known about pediatric inguinal hernias and their treatment.
- Answer: [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
- Quote: "The purpose of this study was to review the current literature and perform a systemic review and meta-analysis to determine the efficacy of LH in the repair of PIH."
- Reasoning: The authors provide an explicit statement of the question being addressed, referencing participants (children with PIH), interventions (LH), comparisons (with OH), outcomes (efficacy of LH), and study design (systematic review and meta-analysis).
- Answer: [Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.
- Quote: Not applicable.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention a review protocol or registration information.
- Answer: [No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.

<PRISMA>
P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
- Quote: "Laparoscopic vs open herniorrhaphy in the management of pediatric inguinal hernia: a systemic review and meta-analysis"
- Reasoning: The title clearly identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
- Answer: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
- Quote: "Abstract: Purpose: Laparoscopic herniorrhaphy (LH) has been evolved as a minimally invasive technique for pediatric inguinal hernias (PIHs). Considerable debate exists regarding the benefits of LH over conventional open herniorrhaphy (OH). The aim of this review was to critique the current literature to determine the efficacy of LH. Methods: Published studies until July 30, 2010, were searched from Medline, Embase, Ovid, Web of Science, and Cochrane databases. Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and observational clinical studies (OCSs) with a comparison of LH and OH were included. A systemic review and meta-analysis were performed using the odds ratios (ORs) for dichotomous variables and weighted mean differences (WMDs) for continuous variables. Results: Of 138 studies, 3 RCTs and 4 OCSs were eligible for inclusion criteria, comprising 1543 cases of LH and 657 cases of OH. Compared with OH, shorter operative time for bilateral hernias (WMD = −11.14; 95% confidence interval [CI], −20.61 to −1.68; P = .02) and lower rate of metachronic contralateral hernia (OR, 0.26; 95% CI, 0.09-0.76; P = .01) were noted in LH. However, no significant difference was observed between LH and OH in patients' age, sex, affected side, operative time for unilateral hernias, duration of hospital stay, time to resume full activity, recurrence, and complications. Conclusions: Laparoscopic herniorrhaphy is superior to OH in the repair of bilateral PIH and lower rate of metachronic contralateral hernia, with similar operative time for unilateral hernias, length of hospital stay, recurrence, and complication rates. Because of the publishing bias, a series of RCTs with standard report format and uniform unit are necessary to explore the efficiencies of LH in the management of PIH."
- Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary of the background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants, interventions, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, and conclusions.
- Answer: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
- Quote: "Inguinal hernias, one of the inguinoscrotal abnormalities because of failure to close the processus vaginalis, are common conditions of infancy and childhood [1]. Herniotomy is the standard procedure for pediatric inguinal hernia (PIH), with a high success rate and low rate of complications [2]. The principle for the repair of PIH is the complete ligation of patent processus vaginalis [3]. Some patients develop hernia on the opposite side after surgical repair, which is known as metachronous contralateral inguinal hernia (MCIH) [4]. Recurrence after an open procedure may be attributed to a failure to ligate the sac high enough at the internal ring, injury to the floor of inguinal canal because of operative trauma, failure to close the internal ring in girls, or postoperative wound infection and hematoma [5]. Therefore, contralateral exploration and postoperative hernia recurrence remain the major problems of conventional open herniorrhaphy (OH) in children with an indirect hernia [5]. In addition, injury to the reproductive system is the most frequent causes of infertility because of childhood inguinal herniorrhaphy [6]. Thus, it remains one of the duties for pediatric surgeons to improve the treatment of inguinal hernias."
- Reasoning: The authors provide a rationale for the review in the context of what is already known about pediatric inguinal hernias and their treatment.
- Answer: [Yes]
