P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.
Quotes: "To complete this study a comprehensive literature review was conducted. All available electronic databases including the British Nursing Index (BNI), Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL), Cochrane Library, EMBASE (Excerpta Medica), Intute: Health & Life Sciences, MEDLINE, PubMed, BIOSIS Previews, ISI Web of Knowledge, ISI Web of Science and IgentaConnect, were systematically searched for each procedure, between the period 1992 – 2009 for all English and non– English language articles."

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.
Quotes: "The keywords used during the search were: “endoscopic surgery, fundoplication, appendectomy and appendicectomy, inguinal hernia, outcomes, minimally invasive surgery, laparoscopy, endoscopy, laparotomy, open surgery, effectiveness, costs, cost-effectiveness, paediatric and pediatric, infant and neonate” . No limits were used."
Reasoning: The authors have presented the search strategy used, including keywords and the fact that no limits were used.
Response: [Yes]

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).
Quotes: "Each article was independently assessed for eligibility using the following criteria: Inclusion criteria ▶ Prospective randomized or prospective non-randomized study format only. ▶ Operative results reported for a “ pediatric population ” , using the words “children, infants or neonates” to describe the study group and including infants, neonates or children (or combinations of the three). ▶ Study subjects under 17 years of age only. ▶ Comparison of laparoscopic and open techniques. ▶ Report on at least one of the outcome measures mentioned previously. ▶ Contain a previously unreported patient group (if patient material was reported more than once, the most informative and recent article was chosen). ▶ When 2 studies were reported by the same institution, the analysis included either the one of better quality, or the most recent publication. Exclusion criteria ▶ Studies in which the outcomes of interest were not reported for the 2 techniques or they were impossible to calculate based on the published results. ▶ Studies that used variations on the standard laparoscopic technique (including hybrid procedures, single-trocar technique procedures). ▶ Studies that included conversions from laparoscopy to open surgery in their analyses (unless individual converted subjects were identifiable and could be excluded from the analysis). ▶ Studies that used variations on the standard open technique (including mini-laparotomy procedures). ▶ Studies in which the standard deviation of the mean for continuous outcomes of interest (length of stay and operative time) were not determinable."

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.
Quotes: None.
Reasoning: The text does not provide information about the data collection process.
Response: [No]

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.
Quotes: "These outcome measures included: ▶ Length of stay (LOS) after the procedure, ▶ Operating room (OR) time, ▶ Frequency of postoperative complications and ▶ Total hospital costs."
Reasoning: The authors have listed and defined all variables for which data were sought.

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.
Quotes: "A level of scientific evidence was assigned to each study identified using the set grading criteria outlined by the US Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality [33, 35] : 1: Prospective, randomized comparative trials, 1A: Systematic review or meta-analysis 2: Prospective, non-randomized comparative trials and 3: Retrospective, observational studies. Only level 1, 1A and 2 studies were included in our analyses."
Reasoning: The authors have described the methods used for assessing the risk of bias of individual studies.
Response: [Yes]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).
Quotes: "For continuous variables (total hospital costs, LOS and OR time), statistical analysis was carried out using weighted mean differences (WMD) as the summary statistic, comparing the laparoscopic treatment groups with the reference (open surgery) groups using the Mantel-Haenszel method."

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.
Quotes: "Meta-analysis was performed in line with recommendations from the Cochrane Collaboration, the Quality of Reporting of Meta-analyses (QUORUM) and MOOSE initiative guidelines, where appropriate."

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).
Quotes: None.

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified.
Quotes: None.
Reasoning: The text does not provide information about additional analyses.

P17. Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.
Quotes: "A total of 24 articles were identified that met the search and inclusion criteria. 16 appendectomy, 4 fundoplication and 4 inguinal hernia studies comparing procedural outcomes method were included."
Reasoning: The authors have given the numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review.

P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.
Quotes: "The study design and methodological quality of the included studies are summarized in Table 1."
Reasoning: The authors mention a table summarizing the characteristics of the included studies.
Response: [Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12).
Quotes: None.
Reasoning: The text does not provide data on the risk of bias of each study.
Response: [No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.
Quotes: "A total of 24 articles were identified that met the search and inclusion criteria. LOS was found to be significantly reduced in favor of the laparoscopic approach, with a weighted mean difference of − 1.44 days, although the OR time was significantly increased, with a weighted mean difference of + 12.8 min. Laparoscopic intervention was associated with a significantly reduced complication rate compared to the open approach (10.6 vs. 15.6 % ). Total hospital costs of the laparoscopic approaches were found to be insignificantly increased compared to the open techniques."
Reasoning: The authors have presented summary data for each intervention group and effect estimates.
Response: [Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
Quotes: "Clearly, LOS is significantly reduced in favor of the laparoscopic approach, with an overall weighted mean difference for LOS of − 1.44 days (95 % CI, − 1.89 to − 0.99, p < 0.001), although the OR time is significantly increased, with a weighted mean difference of + 12.8 min (95 % CI, + 3.7 to + 21.9, p = 0.006), favoring the open surgical technique."
Reasoning: The authors have presented the results of the meta-analysis, including confidence intervals.

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies (see Item P15).
Quotes: None.
Reasoning: The text does not provide results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies.
Response: [No]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression [see Item P16]).
Quotes: None.
Reasoning: The text does not provide results of additional analyses.
Response: [No]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).
Quotes: "This review strengthens the use of MIS in pediatric populations, demonstrating that the three laparoscopic procedures reviewed showed better patient outcomes compared to open procedures in the form of reduced LOS and complication rates."
Reasoning: The authors have summarized the main findings and considered their relevance to key groups.
Response: [Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).
Quotes: "The validity of the results of this review largely depends on the validity of the included studies. Many of the included studies failed to take all the steps necessary to avoid bias. There may well be an inherent bias in the analyses, which are likely to favor the ‘newer’ MIS/laparoscopic technique. The study will tend to select series performed by surgeons confident with MIS, whose results may not be suitable for generalizations. Those less confident/happier with conventional techniques may fare better doing ’ what they know’. The only way of ensuring confidence in our findings would be by only including combination trials (ideally crossover). Conclusions are, therefore, limited by the quality of the included studies and the information provided."
Reasoning: The authors have discussed the limitations at the study and review level.
Response: [Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.

Quotes: None.
Reasoning: The text does not provide information about the sources of funding for the systematic review.
Response: [No]

<PRISMA>
P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
Quotes: "Pediatric Surgical Technique: Laparoscopic or Open Approach? A systematic Review and Meta-Analysis"
Reasoning: The title identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
Response: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
Quotes: "Abstract & Introduction: The laparoscopic treatment of pediatric populations remains controversial. This review was conducted to compare the clinical and cost effectiveness of laparoscopic and open surgical approaches for a variety of surgical indications in pediatric populations. Method/ Design: A computerized comprehensive search supplemented by a manual review of the literature was performed for all peer-reviewed publications comparing laparoscopic and open appendectomy, fundoplication and hernia repair cohorts. Outcomes of interest were length of stay (LOS), operating room (OR) time, complication rates and total hospital costs; aggregation of outcome rates was performed with the Mantel-Haenszel method. Results: A total of 24 articles were identified that met the search and inclusion criteria. LOS was found to be significantly reduced in favor of the laparoscopic approach, with a weighted mean difference of − 1.44 days, although the OR time was significantly increased, with a weighted mean difference of + 12.8 min. Laparoscopic intervention was associated with a significantly reduced complication rate compared to the open approach (10.6 vs. 15.6 % ). Total hospital costs of the laparoscopic approaches were found to be insignificantly increased compared to the open techniques. Conclusion: This review further supports the use of minimally invasive surgery (MIS) in pediatric populations, demonstrating that the three types laparoscopic procedures reviewed resulted in better patient outcomes compared to open procedures, in the form of reduced LOS and overall complication rates. Increased utilization of this approach may prove beneficial to pediatric patients."
Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary of the review.
Response: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
Quotes: "Introduction & Pediatric surgeons were among the pioneers of laparoscopic surgery in the early 1970s, but the vast potential of this “ minimally invasive ” approach to treat neonates, infants and children with surgical conditions has lagged behind its adult counterpart and has only recently begun to be realized [20] . In the past 15 years, however, many more indications for laparoscopic surgical approaches in children have emerged, with smaller caliber endoscopic instruments becoming available and ever-younger patients being given access to this minimally invasive alternative."
Reasoning: The introduction provides the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
Response: [Yes]

<AMSTAR>
A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
- Quote: "The aim of our study is to identify clinical evidence on the reliability of the laparoscopic technique compared to the open techniques, with the end points of recurrence rate and hydrocele formation."
- Reasoning: The authors clearly state the research question and inclusion criteria.
- Answer: [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention the process of study selection and data extraction.
- Answer: [No]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
- Quote: "A literature search was performed, using Medline and Pubmed database, on all articles published during the last 10 years (2000-2009), reporting on varicocele treatments."
- Reasoning: The authors describe the databases used and the time frame for the search, but do not provide keywords or supplementary strategies.
- Answer: [No]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention whether they included grey literature in their search.
- Answer: [No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
- Quote: "We recorded 37 studies, but 26 of these were excluded from our analysis using the following criteria: (1) studies that were not relevant, in which outcome of interest were not reported or were impossible to calculate from the results; and (2) studies not concerning an adolescent population."
- Reasoning: The authors mention the number of studies included and excluded, but do not provide a list of these studies.
- Answer: [No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
- Quote: "Eleven studies published between 2000 and 2009 matched the inclusion criteria, comparing varicocele treatments in the pediatric population, and reporting the incidence of complications."
- Reasoning: The authors provide some characteristics of the included studies, but do not provide detailed information such as participant demographics, interventions, and outcomes.
- Answer: [No]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention assessing the quality of the included studies.
- Answer: [No]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention the quality of the included studies in their conclusions.
- Answer: [No]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
- Quote: "Because of nonhomogeneous studies, we could not apply the meta-analysis method to all studies simultaneously, but we analyzed different meta-analysis grouping studies with similar features."
- Reasoning: The authors describe their approach to combining the findings of the studies.
- Answer: [Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention assessing the likelihood of publication bias.

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention any potential conflicts of interest.

<PRISMA>
P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
- Quote: "Laparoscopic vs open varicocelectomy in children and adolescents: review of the recent literature and meta-analysis"
- Reasoning: The title identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
- Answer: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
- Quote: "Abstract: Purpose: Laparoscopic varicocelectomy has gained popularity in recent years. The aim of this study was to identify clinical evidence about the reliability of this technique in the recent literature. Methods: We performed a Medline search for articles published during the last 10 years, using the key words “varicocele,” “treatment,” and “adolescent.” As limits, we used last 10 years, adolescent, clinical trials, randomized controlled trials, meta-analysis, and multicenter retrospective and prospective studies. The results were investigated in recurrence and hydrocele formation. Results: We pooled 37 studies, but 26 of these were excluded because they were neither relevant nor concerned an adolescent population. Meta-analysis showed that there was no statistical difference between laparoscopic surgery and open surgery in recurrence rate and postoperative hydrocele rate. In the laparoscopic group, the incidence of recurrence was higher in the patients undergoing artery ligation compared to patients undergoing artery and venous ligation. Furthermore, a lower rate of postoperative hydrocele was recorded in patients undergoing dye injections before laparoscopic ligation. Conclusions: Meta-analysis and literature analysis showed that the results after laparoscopic varicocelectomy are comparable to other surgical procedures. The laparoscopic approach has the advantage to treat simultaneously bilateral varicocele."
- Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary of the review, including the background, objectives, methods, results, and conclusions.
- Answer: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
- Quote: "Varicocele is generally considered the most common correctable cause of male infertility [1,2]. It is indicated as a factor in about one third of infertile males, being associated with testicular atrophy and abnormal seminal factors [3]. Varicocele occurs in 10% to 15% of children and adolescents [4,5]. Several treatment options have been used, including spermatic vein sclerotherapy or embolization, open inguinal ligation of the spermatic vein, subinguinal microscopic varicocelectomy, and, most recently, laparoscopy, but the ideal method for varicocele treatment is still controversial [6-8]."
- Reasoning: The authors provide a rationale for the review in the context of what is already known about varicocele and its treatment.
- Answer: [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
- Quote: "The aim of our study is to identify clinical evidence on the reliability of the laparoscopic technique compared to the open techniques, with the end points of recurrence rate and hydrocele formation."
- Reasoning: The authors provide an explicit statement of the questions being addressed, including the participants (children and adolescents with varicocele), interventions (laparoscopic vs open techniques), comparisons (reliability of the techniques), and outcomes (recurrence rate and hydrocele formation).
- Answer: [Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.
- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention a review protocol or registration information.
- Answer: [No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
- Quote: "A literature search was performed, using Medline and Pubmed database, on all articles published during the last 10 years (2000-2009), reporting on varicocele treatments. The following key words were used: “varicocele,” “treatment,” and “adolescent.” Searches were also performed using the following as limits: last 10 years, adolescent, clinical trials, randomized controlled trials, meta-analysis, and multicenter retrospective and prospective studies."
- Reasoning: The authors specify the study characteristics and report characteristics used as criteria for eligibility.
- Answer: [Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.
- Quote: "A literature search was performed, using Medline and Pubmed database, on all articles published during the last 10 years (2000-2009), reporting on varicocele treatments."
- Reasoning: The authors describe the databases used and the time frame for the search, but do not mention the date of the last search.
- Answer: [No]

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.
- Quote: "A literature search was performed, using Medline and Pubmed database, on all articles published during the last 10 years (2000-2009), reporting on varicocele treatments. The following key words were used: “varicocele,” “treatment,” and “adolescent.” Searches were also performed using the following as limits: last 10 years, adolescent, clinical trials, randomized controlled trials, meta-analysis, and multicenter retrospective and prospective studies."
- Reasoning: The authors present the search strategy for the databases used, including the keywords and limits.
- Answer: [Yes]

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).
- Quote: "We recorded 37 studies, but 26 of these were excluded from our analysis using the following criteria: (1) studies that were not relevant, in which outcome of interest were not reported or were impossible to calculate from the results; and (2) studies not concerning an adolescent population."
- Reasoning: The authors state the process for selecting studies, including the criteria for exclusion.
- Answer: [Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.
- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors do not describe the method of data extraction.
- Answer: [No]

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.
- Quote: "Articles with data regarding recurrence, complications (hydrocele, hypotrophy, atrophy), and, if available, semen parameters after treatment were analyzed."
- Reasoning: The authors list the variables for which data were sought, but do not define them or mention any assumptions or simplifications made.
- Answer: [No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.
- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors do not describe methods used for assessing risk of bias in individual studies.
- Answer: [No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).
- Quote: "The results of continuous variables were reported as mean ± SD, and the statistical difference was calculated using the Student's t test. The statistical difference of percentages was calculated by Pearson's χ2."
- Reasoning: The authors state the principal summary measures used in the review.
- Answer: [Yes]

<PRISMA>
P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
- Quote: "Laparoscopic vs open varicocelectomy in children and adolescents: review of the recent literature and meta-analysis"

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
- Quote: "Abstract: Purpose: Laparoscopic varicocelectomy has gained popularity in recent years. The aim of this study was to identify clinical evidence about the reliability of this technique in the recent literature. Methods: We performed a Medline search for articles published during the last 10 years, using the key words “varicocele,” “treatment,” and “adolescent.” As limits, we used last 10 years, adolescent, clinical trials, randomized controlled trials, meta-analysis, and multicenter retrospective and prospective studies. The results were investigated in recurrence and hydrocele formation. Results: We pooled 37 studies, but 26 of these were excluded because they were neither relevant nor concerned an adolescent population. Meta-analysis showed that there was no statistical difference between laparoscopic surgery and open surgery in recurrence rate and postoperative hydrocele rate. In the laparoscopic group, the incidence of recurrence was higher in the patients undergoing artery ligation compared to patients undergoing artery and venous ligation. Furthermore, a lower rate of postoperative hydrocele was recorded in patients undergoing dye injections before laparoscopic ligation. Conclusions: Meta-analysis and literature analysis showed that the results after laparoscopic varicocelectomy are comparable to other surgical procedures. The laparoscopic approach has the advantage to treat simultaneously bilateral varicocele."
- Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary of the review, including the background, objectives, methods, results, and conclusions.
- Answer: [Yes]

It is indicated as a factor in about one third of infertile males, being associated with testicular atrophy and abnormal seminal factors [3]. Varicocele occurs in 10% to 15% of children and adolescents [4,5]. Several treatment options have been used, including spermatic vein sclerotherapy or embolization, open inguinal ligation of the spermatic vein, subinguinal microscopic varicocelectomy, and, most recently, laparoscopy, but the ideal method for varicocele treatment is still controversial [6-8]."

- Quote: "Abstract The ideal management of cryptorchidism is a highly debated topic within the field of pediatric surgery. The optimal timing of orchiopexy is particularly unclear, as existing literature reports mixed recommendations. The aim of this study was to determine, based on a systematic review, the most favorable age at which orchiopexy should be performed. We conducted a systematic search of MEDLINE, Embase, CINAHL, and the Cochrane Library to find relevant articles. Two researchers quality assessed each study using the following tools: AMSTAR (systematic reviews), Jadad (RCTs), and MINORS (non-RCTs). We developed a conclusion based on the highest quality studies. We found one relevant systematic review, one RCT, and 30 non-RCTs. Fertility potential was greatest when orchiopexy was performed before 1 year of age. Additionally, orchiopexy before 10–11 years may protect against the increased risk of testicular cancer associated with cryptorchidism. Orchiopexy should not be performed before 6 months of age, as testes may descend spontaneously during the first few months of life. The highest quality evidence recommends orchiopexy between 6 and 12 months of age. Surgery during this timeframe may optimize fertility potential and protect against testicular malignancy in children with cryptorchidism."

<PRISMA>
P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
- Quote: "Abstract The ideal management of cryptorchidism is a highly debated topic within the field of pediatric surgery. The optimal timing of orchiopexy is particularly unclear, as existing literature reports mixed recommendations. The aim of this study was to determine, based on a systematic review, the most favorable age at which orchiopexy should be performed. We conducted a systematic search of MEDLINE, Embase, CINAHL, and the Cochrane Library to find relevant articles. Two researchers quality assessed each study using the following tools: AMSTAR (systematic reviews), Jadad (RCTs), and MINORS (non-RCTs). We developed a conclusion based on the highest quality studies. We found one relevant systematic review, one RCT, and 30 non-RCTs. Fertility potential was greatest when orchiopexy was performed before 1 year of age. Additionally, orchiopexy before 10–11 years may protect against the increased risk of testicular cancer associated with cryptorchidism. Orchiopexy should not be performed before 6 months of age, as testes may descend spontaneously during the first few months of life. The highest quality evidence recommends orchiopexy between 6 and 12 months of age. Surgery during this timeframe may optimize fertility potential and protect against testicular malignancy in children with cryptorchidism."
- Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary of the study.
- Response: [Yes]

Reasoning: The authors specified the eligibility criteria for the studies.
Response: [Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.
Quotes: "To identify all studies comparing MIS with open surgery for CDH repair, we conducted an electronic search of MEDLINE (1966 onwards), Embase (1980 onwards), and the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL)."
Reasoning: The authors described the information sources used in the search.
Response: [Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.
Quotes: "We used the keywords “diaphragmatic hernia”, “thoracoscopy”, “laparoscopy”, “minimally invasive surgery”, and “open”."
Reasoning: The authors presented the search strategy used for the databases.
Response: [Yes]

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).
Quotes: "Our initial search of MEDLINE, Embase and CENTRAL yielded 160 studies (Fig. 1). After applying our exclusion criteria, 9 studies remained. We identified one additional relevant study through hand-searching, thus we included 10 studies in total [8–17]."
Reasoning: The authors described the process for selecting studies.
Response: [Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.
Quotes: No relevant quotes found.

Quotes: "Our primary outcome of interest was hernia recurrence after surgery. Secondary outcomes included operative time, total length of stay (LOS), postoperative ventilator time and postoperative mortality."
Reasoning: The authors listed and defined the variables for which data were sought.
Response: [Yes]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.
Quotes: "Two researchers independently assessed each study for methodological quality using MINORS."
Reasoning: The authors described the methods used for assessing the risk of bias in individual studies.
Response: [Yes]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).
Quotes: "We used weighted mean differences to analyze continuous data and odds ratios to analyze categorical variables."
Reasoning: The authors stated the principal summary measures.
Response: [Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.
Quotes: "For each outcome, we first assessed the heterogeneity of the studies (Chi 2 test and I 2 statistic). When heterogeneity was low to moderate (Q test p N 0.10, I 2 b 50%), we used a fixed-effects model. <PRISMA>
P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
- Quote: "Transanal endorectal pull-through versus transabdominal approach for Hirschsprung's disease: A systematic review and meta-analysis"
- Reasoning: The title identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
- Answer: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
- Quote: "Abstract: Aim: Transanal endorectal pull-through (TERPT) has become popular for single-stage treatment of Hirschsprung's disease. The benefits of TERPT over the conventional transabdominal approach (TAB) are still unclear. We performed a comprehensive meta-analysis comparing the clinical outcomes of TERPT and TAB. Methods: Original articles published from 1998 to 2012 were searched from Medline, Embase, and Cochrane databases. Randomized controlled trials (RCT) and observational clinical studies (OCS) comparing TERPT and TAB were included. Outcomes evaluated included operative time, hospital stay and incidence of postoperative incontinence/soiling, constipation and enterocolitis. Pooled odds ratios (OR) were calculated for dichotomous variables; pooled mean differences (MD) were measured for continuous variables. Results: Of 93 studies, 1 RCT and 11 OCS were included, comprising 444 cases of TERPT and 348 cases of TAB (215 Soave, 94 Duhamel, 24 Swenson, 15 Rehbein procedures). TERPT had shorter operative time (MD = −57.85 min; 95% confidence interval [CI], −83.11 to − 32.60; P b 0.00001) and hospital stay (MD = −7.06 days; 95% CI, −10.95 to −3.16; P = 0.0004). TERPT had less postoperative incontinence/ soiling (OR = 0.58; 95% CI 0.37–0.90; P = 0.01) and constipation (OR = 0.49; 95% CI 0.30–0.81; P = 0.005). There was no difference in incidence of postoperative enterocolitis. Conclusion: TERPT is superior to TAB in operative time, hospital stay, postoperative incontinence and constipation. However, more randomized controlled trials are necessary to verify the benefit of TERPT for Hirschsprung's disease."
- Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary of the background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants, interventions, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, and conclusions.
- Answer: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.

For many years, surgical treatment of HD involved staged procedures; an initial diverting enterostomy was followed by definitive transabdominal pull-through surgery with subsequent closure of the colostomy. These multi-stage surgeries have gradually been replaced by the primary pull-through surgery in many centers [7]."
- Reasoning: The authors provided a rationale for the review in the context of what is already known about the surgical treatment of Hirschsprung's disease.

- Reasoning: The authors mention assessing the risk of bias within studies using the MINORS criteria, but they do not present the data on risk of bias for each study.
- Response: [No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.
- Quote: "These 9 studies included a cumulative total of 414 patients managed expectantly, that is, ‘‘asymptomatic patients’’ in whom no IRA screening was undertaken (group A), 191 cases in whom screening was performed routinely (group B), and 92 patients who were considered ‘‘symptomatic’’ of potential rotational anomalies and therefore underwent imaging or laparotomy (group C)."
- Reasoning: The authors present summary data for each group of patients in the included studies, but they do not provide effect estimates and confidence intervals for each study.
- Response: [No]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
- Quote: Not applicable.
- Reasoning: The authors did not perform a meta-analysis.
- Response: [NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies (see Item P15).
- Quote: Not applicable.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention assessing for risk of bias across studies.
- Response: [No]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression [see Item P16]).
- Quote: Not applicable.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention conducting any additional analyses.
- Response: [NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).
- Quote: "This systematic review shows that ‘‘asymptomatic patients’’ with heterotaxy are at a low risk of developing IRA-related complications. Of 414 patients managed expectantly, only a single patient (0.24%) developed symptoms directly attributable to IRA during the total follow-up period."
- Reasoning: The authors summarize the main findings of the review and discuss their relevance.
- Response: [Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).
- Quote: "We fully acknowledge that there are some limitations with the present study. Follow-up reporting data in studies we analyzed was sometimes poor. This may influence long-term outcome(s) of both a ‘‘watchful waiting’’ policy and operative intervention. Adequate reporting in studies was thus by no means always satisfactory."
- Reasoning: The authors discuss the limitations of the review, including issues with follow-up reporting data and the quality of reporting in the included studies.
- Response: [Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.
- Quote: "Given the fragility of this patient cohort—with cardiac comorbidity(s)—many can therefore avoid an unnecessary Ladd’s operation."
- Reasoning: The authors provide a general interpretation of the results and discuss their implications.
- Response: [Yes]

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.
- Quote: "No funding was sought or received for this work."
- Reasoning: The authors disclose that they did not receive any funding for the review.
- Response: [Yes]

llm_message:
<AMSTAR>
A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quotes: "The study protocol was registered on the PROSPERO international prospective database of systematic reviews (CRD42013003969) and analysis was performed in accordance with recommendations outlined in the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) Statement [5]."
Reasoning: The authors mention that the study protocol was registered on the PROSPERO database, indicating an 'a priori' design.
Response: [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
Quotes: "Two authors independently undertook literature searches, screened abstracts, and assessed eligible articles against inclusion criteria (T.P.C., A.H.H.). There was 90% agreement on identification of articles and discrepancies were resolved by consensus, or arbitrated by a third author (E.K.M.)."
Reasoning: The authors mention that two authors independently conducted the literature search and data extraction, and any disagreements were resolved by consensus or a third author.
Response: [Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quotes: "Systematic literature searches were undertaken of the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), PubMed, Ovid Medline and EMBASE electronic databases using the following search strategy using the following Medical Subject Headings (MeSH): (‘Surgery, Computer-Assisted’ OR ‘robotics’ OR ‘da Vinci’ OR ‘telerobotic’ OR ‘telesurgery’ OR ‘robotic surgery’) AND (‘Pediatrics’ OR ‘Infant’ OR ‘Child’ OR ‘Adolescent’) AND (‘Kidney’ OR ‘Pelvi-ureteric Junction Obstruction’ OR ‘Pyeloplasty’). The search was conducted up to December 2013. The primary search was supplemented with searches of: i) PubMed related articles feature, ii) clinicaltrials.gov registry using the keyword ‘pyeloplasty’, and iii) abstracts of the International Pediatric Endosurgery Group Annual Congresses (2002–2013), the AUA Annual Meetings (2006–2013), Section of Urology Program of the American Association of Pediatrics National Conference (2007–2012), and World Congress of Endourology (2008–2013)."
Reasoning: The authors performed a comprehensive literature search using multiple databases and supplementary strategies.
Response: [Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
Quotes: No specific quotes related to this criterion.
Reasoning: The authors do not mention whether they included grey literature in their search.
Response: [No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
Quotes: No specific quotes related to this criterion.
Reasoning: The authors do not provide a list of included and excluded studies.
Response: [No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quotes: "In all, 12 observational studies met inclusion criteria, reporting outcomes of 384 RAP, 131 LP, and 164 OP procedures. No randomised controlled trials were identified."
Reasoning: The authors provide some information about the characteristics of the included studies, but not in a detailed or aggregated form.
Response: [No]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quotes: "The methodological quality of studies was appraised using a star-based modified Newcastle-Ottawa Scale (mNOS) that considers patient selection, inter-group comparability, and outcome assessment (maximum 3, 10, and 2 stars respectively; total out of 15) [6]."
Reasoning: The authors mention that they assessed the quality of the included studies using the Newcastle-Ottawa Scale.
Response: [Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
Quotes: "The median (range) mNOS score was 9 (4–14) (Table 4)."
Reasoning: The authors mention the quality scores of the included studies, but do not explicitly state how these scores were used in formulating their conclusions.
Response: [No]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
Quotes: "Statistical analysis was conducted using Review Manager ® Version 5.1.7 for Windows (The Cochrane Collaboration, Software Update, Oxford, UK) and STATA v.11 statistical analysis software (StataCorp LP, TX, USA). A weighted random-effects model was used for all analyses."
Reasoning: The authors describe the statistical methods used to combine the findings of the included studies.
Response: [Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
Quotes: "Risk of publication bias was assessed by visual inspection of funnel plots in addition to statistical estimation with both Begg and Mazumdar’s test and Egger’s test for small study effects."
Reasoning: The authors mention that they assessed the likelihood of publication bias using funnel plots and statistical tests.
Response: [Yes]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
Quotes: No specific quotes related to this criterion.
Reasoning: The authors do not mention any conflicts of interest for the systematic review or the included studies.
Response: [No]

<PRISMA>
P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
Quotes: "Meta-analysis of robot-assisted vs conventional laparoscopic and open pyeloplasty in children"
Reasoning: The title identifies the report as a meta-analysis.
Response: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
Quotes: The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants, interventions, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, conclusions and implications of key findings, and systematic review registration number.
Reasoning: The abstract includes all the necessary components of a structured summary.
Response: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
Quotes: "Pyeloplasty is the most prevalently reported and highest volume application of robot-assisted minimally invasive surgery in children [1]. There is now an abundance of case reports and case series that clearly show the safety and feasibility of robot-assisted pyeloplasty (RAP) in paediatric populations [1]."
Reasoning: The authors provide a rationale for the review in the context of existing knowledge.
Response: [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
Quotes: "The aim of the present study was therefore to undertake a meta-analysis of RAP vs LP and OP in children."
Reasoning: The authors provide an explicit statement of the questions being addressed, referencing participants, interventions, comparisons, and outcomes.
Response: [Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.
Quotes: "The study protocol was registered on the PROSPERO international prospective database of systematic reviews (CRD42013003969) and analysis was performed in accordance with recommendations outlined in the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) Statement [5]."
Reasoning: The authors mention that the review protocol was registered on the PROSPERO database and provide the registration number.
Response: [Yes]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
Quotes: "All included studies satisfied the following criteria: i) comparing RAP vs LP and/or OP; ii) involving paediatric patients with mean study group ages of <18 years; iii) reporting five or more patients in each study group; iv) involving singular pathologies or procedures; and v) investigating objective clinical outcome measures or cost. No language restrictions were imposed. In the event of duplication of data, more recent studies or those with larger sample sizes were preferentially considered."
Reasoning: The authors specify the study characteristics and report characteristics used as criteria for eligibility.
Response: [Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.
Quotes: "Systematic literature searches were undertaken of the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), PubMed, Ovid Medline and EMBASE electronic databases using the following search strategy using the following Medical Subject Headings (MeSH): (‘Surgery, Computer-Assisted’ OR ‘robotics’ OR ‘da Vinci’ OR ‘telerobotic’ OR ‘telesurgery’ OR ‘robotic surgery’) AND (‘Pediatrics’ OR ‘Infant’ OR ‘Child’ OR ‘Adolescent’) AND (‘Kidney’ OR ‘Pelvi-ureteric Junction Obstruction’ OR ‘Pyeloplasty’). The search was conducted up to December 2013. The primary search was supplemented with searches of: i) PubMed related articles feature, ii) clinicaltrials.gov registry using the keyword ‘pyeloplasty’, and iii) abstracts of the International Pediatric Endosurgery Group Annual Congresses (2002–2013), the AUA Annual Meetings (2006–2013), Section of Urology Program of the American Association of Pediatrics National Conference (2007–2012), and World Congress of Endourology (2008–2013)."
Reasoning: The authors describe all the information sources used in the search and the date the search was last conducted.
Response: [Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.
Quotes: "Systematic literature searches were undertaken of the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), PubMed, Ovid Medline and EMBASE electronic databases using the following search strategy using the following Medical Subject Headings (MeSH): (‘Surgery, Computer-Assisted’ OR ‘robotics’ OR ‘da Vinci’ OR ‘telerobotic’ OR ‘telesurgery’ OR ‘robotic surgery’) AND (‘Pediatrics’ OR ‘Infant’ OR ‘Child’ OR ‘Adolescent’) AND (‘Kidney’ OR ‘Pelvi-ureteric Junction Obstruction’ OR ‘Pyeloplasty’). The search was conducted up to December 2013."
Reasoning: The authors present the full electronic search strategy for multiple databases.
Response: [Yes]

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).
Quotes: "Two authors independently undertook literature searches, screened abstracts, and assessed eligible articles against inclusion criteria (T.P.C., A.H.H.). There was 90% agreement on identification of articles and discrepancies were resolved by consensus, or arbitrated by a third author (E.K.M.)."
Reasoning: The authors describe the process for selecting studies.
Response: [Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.
Quotes: "Two authors independently undertook literature searches, screened abstracts, and assessed eligible articles against inclusion criteria (T.P.C., A.H.H.). There was 90% agreement on identification of articles and discrepancies were resolved by consensus, or arbitrated by a third author (E.K.M.)."
Reasoning: The authors describe the method of data extraction from reports.
Response: [Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.
Quotes: "Primary outcomes of interest were operative success, requirement for re-operation, conversion rates, postoperative complications, and urinary leakage complication rates. Secondary outcome measures were estimated blood loss (EBL), length of hospital stay (LOS), operating time (OT), analgesia requirement, and cost."
Reasoning: The authors list and define all variables for which data were sought.
Response: [Yes]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.
Quotes: "The methodological quality of studies was appraised using a star-based modified Newcastle-Ottawa Scale (mNOS) that considers patient selection, inter-group comparability, and outcome assessment (maximum 3, 10, and 2 stars respectively; total out of 15) [6]."
Reasoning: The authors describe the methods used for assessing the risk of bias in individual studies.
Response: [Yes]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).
Quotes: "A weighted random-effects model was used for all analyses. Pooled odds ratios (ORs) were calculated as the summary statistic for dichotomous variables and weighted mean difference (WMD) calculated for continuous variables. Both ORs and WMDs are reported with 95% CIs."
Reasoning: The authors state the principal summary measures used in the review.
Response: [Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.
Quotes: "Statistical analysis was conducted using Review Manager ® Version 5.1.7 for Windows (The Cochrane Collaboration, Software Update, Oxford, UK) and STATA v.11 statistical analysis software (StataCorp LP, TX, USA). A weighted random-effects model was used for all analyses."
Reasoning: The authors describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies.
Response: [Yes]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).
Quotes: "Risk of publication bias was assessed by visual inspection of funnel plots in addition to statistical estimation with both Begg and Mazumdar’s test and Egger’s test for small study effects."
Reasoning: The authors specify the assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence.
Response: [Yes]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified.
Quotes: No specific quotes related to this criterion.
Reasoning: The authors do not mention any additional analyses.
Response: [No]

P17. Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.
Quotes: "In all, 12 observational studies met inclusion criteria, reporting outcomes of 384 RAP, 131 LP, and 164 OP procedures. No randomised controlled trials were identified."
Reasoning: The authors give the numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, but do not provide reasons for exclusions at each stage or a flow diagram.
Response: [No]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.
Quotes: "In all, 12 observational studies met inclusion criteria, reporting outcomes of 384 RAP, 131 LP, and 164 OP procedures. No randomised controlled trials were identified."
Reasoning: The authors present some characteristics for each study, but do not provide the citations.
Response: [No]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12).
Quotes: "The median (range) mNOS score was 9 (4–14) (Table 4)."
Reasoning: The authors present data on the risk of bias of each study.
Response: [Yes]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.
Quotes: The authors present simple summary data for each intervention group, effect estimates and confidence intervals, and forest plots for all outcomes considered.
Reasoning: The authors present the results of individual studies for all outcomes considered.
Response: [Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
Quotes: The authors present the results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
Reasoning: The authors present the synthesis of results for each meta-analysis done.
Response: [Yes]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies (see Item P15).
Quotes: "Risk of publication bias was assessed by visual inspection of funnel plots in addition to statistical estimation with both Begg and Mazumdar’s test and Egger’s test for small study effects."
Reasoning: The authors present the results of the assessment of risk of bias across studies.
Response: [Yes]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression [see Item P16]).
Quotes: No specific quotes related to this criterion.
Reasoning: The authors do not mention any additional analyses.
Response: [No]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).
Quotes: "Meta-analysis of the current literature identifies no significant differences between RAP and LP or OP for the five primary outcome variables assessed. Significant differences in favour of RAP were found for secondary outcome variables of EBL (vs OP) and LOS (vs LP and OP). OT was found to be significantly longer for RAP vs OP. Limited evidence from observational studies indicates lower opiate analgesia requirement for RAP (vs LP and OP), higher total costs for RAP vs OP, and comparable costs for RAP vs LP."
Reasoning: The authors summarize the main findings and the strength of evidence for each main outcome.
Response: [Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).
Quotes: "No randomised controlled trials were identified. Unfortunately, this is not unusual despite these trials being considered the ‘gold-standard’ method of comparative assessment [27]. A distinct absence of prospective studies was also identified. The reliance upon less robust retrospective data are inadequate and represents a major weakness in the current literature base for paediatric robot-assisted surgery [1]."
Reasoning: The authors discuss the limitations at the study and review level.
Response: [Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.
Quotes: "There is a strong need for higher quality evidence in the form of prospective observational studies and clinical trials, as well as further cost-effectiveness analyses."
Reasoning: The authors provide a general interpretation of the results and implications for future research.
Response: [Yes]

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.
Quotes: No specific quotes related to this criterion.
Reasoning: The authors do not mention any sources of funding for the systematic review.
Response: [No]

<AMSTAR>
A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
- Quote: "Therefore, the authors collected all studies published since 1992 that compared SILA versus TILA to perform a meta-analysis and investigated the safety and efficacy of two approaches in the treatment of appendicitis."
- Reasoning: The authors state that they planned to perform a meta-analysis comparing SILA and TILA, but they do not mention a protocol or pre-determined objectives.
- Answer: [No]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
- Quote: "Three researchers extracted data from each study by using a structured sheet and entered the data into a database."
- Reasoning: The authors mention that three researchers were involved in data extraction, but they do not specify if this was done independently or if there was a consensus process for disagreements.
- Answer: [No]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
- Quote: "The publications were identified by searching the major medical databases such as MEDLINE, EMBASE, and Cochrane Library for relevant papers published between January 1992 and July 2012."
- Reasoning: The authors describe their search strategy and the databases they used, but they do not mention any supplementary strategies.
- Answer: [Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention searching for grey literature or including/excluding studies based on their publication status.
- Answer: [No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
- Quote: "According to the search strategy and inclusion criteria, a total of 17 studies [5,15–30] that included 1809 appendicectomy cases (793 SILA and 1016 TILA) were considered suitable for meta-analysis."
- Reasoning: The authors mention the number of studies included in their meta-analysis and provide references, but they do not provide a list of excluded studies.
- Answer: [No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
- Quote: "The characteristics of the 17 studies (1 randomized controlled trial [22] and 16 retrospective studies [5,15–21,23–30]) are shown in Table 1."

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
- Quote: "We used a star scoring system [12] based on criteria related to study design, comparability of patient groups, and outcome assessment to assess literature quality."
- Reasoning: The authors describe their method for assessing the quality of the included studies.
- Answer: [Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
- Quote: "Most of the studies included in our meta-analysis were retrospective studies, which could have led to some selection bias."
- Reasoning: The authors acknowledge the limitations of their study, including the quality of the included studies.

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
- Quote: "Statistically, it was not possible to combine the analysis of mean and median, and only data in the form of means and standard deviation were included in the meta-analysis."
- Reasoning: The authors describe their method for combining the findings of the included studies.

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?

- Reasoning: The authors assess the likelihood of publication bias using a funnel plot.

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?

<PRISMA>
P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
- Quote: "Single-incision versus conventional three-incision laparoscopic appendicectomy for appendicitis: A systematic review and meta-analysis"
- Reasoning: The title clearly identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
- Answer: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
- Quote: "Abstract: Background: This meta-analysis was designed to investigate the safety and efficacy of single-incision laparoscopic appendicectomy (SILA) and three-incision laparoscopic appendicectomy (TILA) in the treatment of appendicitis. Materials and Methods: Studies published since 1992 that compared SILA versus TILA in laparoscopic appendicectomy were collected. Data on operative parameters, postoperative recovery, postoperative pain and complications, and hospitalization costs for SILA and TILA were meta-analyzed using fixed-effect and random-effect models. Results: Seventeen studies (1 randomized controlled trial and 16 retrospective studies) that included 1809 patients were studied. Of these patients, 793 and 1016 had undergone SILA and TILA, respectively. There was significantly shorter length of hospital stay; however, there were evidently higher conversion rate, and perhaps higher surgical difficulty and hospitalization costs for SILA compared with TILA. Other outcome variables such as operative time, blood loss, time to first oral intake, postoperative pain and complications were not found to be statistically significant for either group. Conclusions: Compared with TILA, SILA has the advantage of shorter hospital stay, and it can achieve comparable operative time, blood loss, postoperative recovery, postoperative pain and complications with TILA. The drawback is that SILA is associated with higher conversion rate, and perhaps higher surgical difficulty and hospitalization costs. Whether it can achieve improvement in cosmesis remains to be confirmed."
- Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary of the background, objectives, methods, results, and conclusions.
- Answer: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
- Quote: "Single-incision laparoscopic surgery (SILS) is the novel member of the minimally invasive surgery [4], it's a new innovation allowing minimal invasive surgery to be performed through a single umbilical incision, and it can further reduce the trauma of surgical access [5]. SILS has made great strides forward in general surgery, urological and gynecological surgery in recent years [6–11], its treatment for appendicitis (i.e. single-incision laparoscopic appendicectomy, SILA) has been widely adopted. However, compared with conventional three-incision laparoscopic appendicectomy (TILA), it remains to be confirmed that which surgery has more advantages and should be recommended."
- Reasoning: The authors provide a rationale for their review in the context of the current state of knowledge.
- Answer: [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
- Quote: "Therefore, the authors collected all studies published since 1992 that compared SILA versus TILA to perform a meta-analysis and investigated the safety and efficacy of two approaches in the treatment of appendicitis."
- Reasoning: The authors clearly state the objectives of their review, including the participants (patients with appendicitis), interventions (SILA and TILA), comparisons (between SILA and TILA), and outcomes (safety and efficacy).
- Answer: [Yes]

Exclusion criteria were: (1) no three-incision laparoscopic appendectomy as a control; (2) secondary appendicitis; (3) duplicate publication or the publication did not provide sufficient data."

<PRISMA>
P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
- Quote: "Single-incision versus conventional three-incision laparoscopic appendicectomy for appendicitis: A systematic review and meta-analysis"
- Reasoning: The title clearly identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
- Answer: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
- Quote: "Abstract: Background: This meta-analysis was designed to investigate the safety and efficacy of single-incision laparoscopic appendicectomy (SILA) and three-incision laparoscopic appendicectomy (TILA) in the treatment of appendicitis. Materials and Methods: Studies published since 1992 that compared SILA versus TILA in laparoscopic appendicectomy were collected. Data on operative parameters, postoperative recovery, postoperative pain and complications, and hospitalization costs for SILA and TILA were meta-analyzed using fixed-effect and random-effect models. Results: Seventeen studies (1 randomized controlled trial and 16 retrospective studies) that included 1809 patients were studied. Of these patients, 793 and 1016 had undergone SILA and TILA, respectively. There was significantly shorter length of hospital stay; however, there were evidently higher conversion rate, and perhaps higher surgical difficulty and hospitalization costs for SILA compared with TILA. Other outcome variables such as operative time, blood loss, time to first oral intake, postoperative pain and complications were not found to be statistically significant for either group. Conclusions: Compared with TILA, SILA has the advantage of shorter hospital stay, and it can achieve comparable operative time, blood loss, postoperative recovery, postoperative pain and complications with TILA. The drawback is that SILA is associated with higher conversion rate, and perhaps higher surgical difficulty and hospitalization costs. Whether it can achieve improvement in cosmesis remains to be confirmed."
- Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary of the background, objectives, methods, results, and conclusions.
- Answer: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
- Quote: "Single-incision laparoscopic surgery (SILS) is the novel member of the minimally invasive surgery [4], it's a new innovation allowing minimal invasive surgery to be performed through a single umbilical incision, and it can further reduce the trauma of surgical access [5]. SILS has made great strides forward in general surgery, urological and gynecological surgery in recent years [6–11], its treatment for appendicitis (i.e. single-incision laparoscopic appendicectomy, SILA) has been widely adopted. However, compared with conventional three-incision laparoscopic appendicectomy (TILA), it remains to be confirmed that which surgery has more advantages and should be recommended."
- Reasoning: The authors provide a rationale for their review in the context of the current state of knowledge.
- Answer: [Yes]

Exclusion criteria were: (1) no three-incision laparoscopic appendectomy as a control; (2) secondary appendicitis; (3) duplicate publication or the publication did not provide sufficient data."

- Reasoning: The authors clearly stated their research question and objectives before conducting the review.

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
- Quote: "We systematically searched PubMed for relevant studies reported from 2005 to 2014 with the keywords “laparoscopic herniorrhaphy”, “pediatric inguinal hernia,” and “open herniorrhaphy.” Total reference lists of selected articles were also included."

- Quote: Not provided.

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
- Quote: "This meta-analysis favors LH in the repair of bilateral hernias and for unilateral hernias in extraperitoneal approaches’ group. Total postoperative complications were significantly reduced in LH, especially for major postoperative complications in male children."

- Response: [No]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
- Quote: "Weighted mean differences and odds ratios were used for the analysis of continuous and dichotomous variables, respectively."
- Reasoning: The authors described the statistical methods they used to combine the findings of the studies.

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
- Quote: Not provided.
- Reasoning: The authors did not mention whether they assessed the likelihood of publication bias.

<PRISMA>
P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
- Quote: "Comparison of LILT and STEP procedures in children with short bowel syndrome — A systematic review of the literature"
- Reasoning: The title clearly identifies the report as a systematic review.

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
- Quote: "Abstract: Purpose: To compare LILT and STEP, the two principal procedures to lengthen the native bowel in children with a short bowel syndrome (SBS), by discussing the indications and presenting the outcome from published data. Methods: A review of literature was performed. N = 39 publications were reviewed. Results: For LILT and STEP, failure to achieve intestinal autonomy by conservative therapy represents the main indication, and end-stage liver disease the main contraindication. A sufficiently dilated intestinal segment is a common anatomical precondition for both procedures. STEP can be performed on shorter intestinal segments and on intricate segments such as the duodenum, which is technically not feasible for LILT. Both procedures have a similar extent of intestinal lengthening (approximately 70%) and result in improvement of enteral nutrition and reversal of complications of parenteral nutrition. STEP seems to have a lower mortality and overall progression to transplantation. Conclusions: STEP and LILT are both accepted procedures for non-transplant surgical management of SBS in children. The outcome after STEP seems to be more favourable, but larger series are needed to further assess accurate selection of eligible patients and to estimate effectiveness of procedures. A considerably higher number of cases for evaluation might be accomplished through the widespread use of a centralised registry."
- Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary of the background, objectives, methods, results, and conclusions.
- Answer: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
- Quote: "Short bowel syndrome (SBS) is a serious disorder in which the intestinal resorptive capacity is insufficient to provide an adequate alimentary supply [1]. The estimated incidence in children is 24.5 per 100,000 live births with a higher incidence reported in preterm infants [2]. The estimated mortality is 2/100,000 population/year for children with SBS under 4 years [2] and 37.5% of neonates with SBS [3]. SBS in children occurs after congenital or acquired loss of part of the intestine [4], in most cases due to gastroschisis, necrotizing enterocolitis, mid-gut volvulus and intestinal atresia [5]."
